sections.title: Introduction to DC Motors
sections.content: DC motors are the primary actuators in FTC robots, providing the mechanical force needed for movement, lifting, and other mechanical functions. Understanding how to properly control and configure DC motors is fundamental to successful robot programming.

sections.title: What are DC Motors?
sections.subtitle: Key characteristics of DC motors:
items: Convert electrical energy into rotational motion
Speed and direction are controlled by voltage and polarity
Torque output depends on motor type and gearing
Built-in encoders provide position feedback
Can be controlled with precise power levels (-1.0 to 1.0)

sections.title: FTC Motor Types
sections.content: FTC allows several types of DC motors, each with unique characteristics suitable for different applications.

sections.title: Common FTC Motors
items: AndyMark Neverest: 20, 40, and 60 series with different speed/torque ratios
REV HD Hex Motor: High precision with built-in encoder
GoBilda Yellow Jacket: Various options with different gear ratios
REV Core Hex Motor: Compact motor for space-constrained applications

sections.title: Motor Specifications Comparison
Motor Configuration
sections.content: Proper motor configuration is essential for reliable operation. This includes setting directions, modes, and power limits.

sections.title: Basic Motor Setup
Motor Control Methods
sections.content: There are several ways to control motors in FTC, each suitable for different applications.

sections.title: Control Methods
items: Power Control: Direct power setting (-1.0 to 1.0)
Encoder Control: Position-based control using encoders
Velocity Control: Speed-based control with PID
Run Modes: Different operating modes for various needs

sections.title: Motor Control Examples
Motor Safety
sections.content: Safety is paramount when working with motors. Always implement proper safety measures to prevent damage to your robot and injury to team members.

sections.title: Safety Guidelines
sections.subtitle: Follow these safety practices:
items: Always test motors at low power first
Keep hands and loose objects away from moving parts
Use emergency stop functionality
Monitor motor temperature during extended use
Check for binding or mechanical issues
Implement power limits in your code

sections.title: Safety Implementation
Troubleshooting Motors
sections.content: Common motor issues and their solutions help teams quickly resolve problems during competitions and practice.

sections.title: Common Issues and Solutions
items: Motor runs in wrong direction: Change setDirection() or swap motor wires
Motor doesn't respond: Check configuration file and wiring
Uneven motor speeds: Calibrate power levels or check mechanical binding
Motor gets hot: Reduce power or check for mechanical resistance
Encoder issues: Check encoder cable and configuration

sections.title: DC Motor Practice
sections.description: Practice these exercises to master motor control:
tasks: Create a simple OpMode that controls one motor with gamepad input
Test different motor directions and verify correct movement
Implement power limiting and safety features
Test encoder functionality and position control
Create a drivetrain with four motors
Test motor behavior with different battery levels
